author: Deborah Baker / Journal Staff Writer
title: Politics Notebook: Senate Majority Leader Sanchez attends worker summit at White House
text:
New Mexico Senate Majority Leader Michael Sanchez was at the White House on Wednesday, one of six people on an opening panel – moderated by U.S. Labor Secretary Tom Perez – for President Barack Obama’s “Worker Voice Summit.”
The focus of the daylong summit was to explore ways of ensuring that working Americans fully share in the benefits of the economic growth they help create, according to the White House.
Business, union and government leaders were on hand.
Asked by Perez about the New Mexico state Senate’s blocking so-called right-to-work legislation this year, the Belen Democrat said he doesn’t use the term right-to-work for the bill, which had the backing of GOP Gov. Susana Martinez and the Republican-led House.
“I call it anti-worker legislation, because that is what it is,” he said.
He also said collective bargaining has resulted in safer working conditions, 40-hour workweeks, higher salaries, paid sick leave, health care benefits and retirement pensions.
The day included remarks by Obama and a town hall with him.
At least one other New Mexican also was at the summit: Carmella Salinas, an early childhood educator in Española and a member of New Mexico Early Educators United, an affiliate of the American Federation of Teachers. Salinas is president of PEOPLE for the Kids, a partnership of educators, parents and early learning center owners.
AG GALLERY: Attorney General Hector Balderas and some of his predecessors will officially dedicate a portrait gallery of New Mexico’s AGs dating back to territorial days at the Santa Fe office on Friday.
Former U.S. Sen. Fred Harris will moderate the program, which will include remarks by Balderas and these former attorneys general: former U.S. Sen. Jeff Bingaman, former Gov. Toney Anaya, Paul Bardacke, Gary King, David Norvell and Hal Stratton.
The portrait gallery – mostly photos – honors attorneys general reaching back to 1846. Located just off the main lobby of the AG’s Office, the Hall of Attorneys General will be open to the public during office hours.
The dedication ceremony will be held at 3 p.m. Friday in the courtyard next to the office.
New Mexico has had 51 attorneys general. The only woman among them, Patricia Madrid, had a scheduling conflict, according to a spokesman for Balderas.
